title: Cash structuring/smurfing via ABM (many small cash txns)
plain_english_explanation: Many small cash deposits/withdrawals in a short period, often clustered near reporting/monitoring thresholds, can indicate structuring (smurfing).
ocg_relevance: Common placement method used by OCGs and professional money launderers to avoid detection thresholds.
how_to_use: Compute cash transaction counts/sums in rolling windows; flag unusually high frequency + amounts concentrated just below a threshold or unusually repetitive.
caveats_false_positives: Cash-intensive legitimate activity; payroll cash handling; holidays/events.

title: Near-threshold cash banding (amounts repeatedly just below T)
plain_english_explanation: Repeated cash transactions narrowly below a monitoring threshold may suggest deliberate threshold avoidance.
ocg_relevance: OCGs and money laundering facilitators may standardize ticket sizes to evade rules.
how_to_use: Define one or more thresholds T; compute share of cash amounts within [0.8T,1.0T); flag high concentration and repetition.
caveats_false_positives: Some businesses use consistent deposit tickets; ATM limits may shape amounts.
external_enrichment_needed: Choose thresholds relevant to your institution/regime.

title: Round-dollar cash pattern (excessive round deposits/withdrawals)
plain_english_explanation: Unusually frequent round-dollar cash amounts (e.g., multiples of 100/1000) can indicate non-organic cash handling.
ocg_relevance: OCG cash often comes in packaged denominations; fronts may report rounded deposits.
how_to_use: Compute pct_round_dollar among cash transactions; flag outliers vs customer baseline and peer group.
caveats_false_positives: Legitimate cash businesses often deposit round numbers.

title: Cash deposit → rapid outbound transfers (cash-to-electronic sequencing)
plain_english_explanation: Cash is deposited and then quickly moved out via electronic channels, reducing the chance of tracing the cash source.
ocg_relevance: Layering tactic seen in professional laundering to distance cash from origin quickly.
how_to_use: Identify sequences: ABM cash credit followed by outbound EFT/EMT/Wire within N hours; count and score sequence intensity.
caveats_false_positives: Legitimate cash deposit followed by bill payments; business cash management.

title: Inbound electronic credit → rapid cash withdrawal (cash-out)
plain_english_explanation: Funds arrive electronically and are quickly withdrawn as cash, consistent with mule cash-out behavior.
ocg_relevance: OCGs often rely on mules to withdraw and disperse funds rapidly.
how_to_use: Detect credit→cash sequences: any EFT/EMT/Wire credit followed by ABM cash debit within N hours; flag high frequency.

title: Cash churn (alternating deposits and withdrawals)
plain_english_explanation: Frequent alternating cash deposits and withdrawals can indicate cycling funds to create noise and obscure origin.
ocg_relevance: Churning is a common laundering ‘obfuscation’ behavior when combined with other signals.
how_to_use: Measure alternation rate (C→D→C) and short inter-arrival times; flag churny behavior.
caveats_false_positives: Some customers move cash for operational reasons (e.g., retail change).

title: Cash activity spikes soon after onboarding
plain_english_explanation: A new account shows unusually high cash activity shortly after onboarding compared to typical new customers.
ocg_relevance: Burner/mule/front accounts are often used intensely early, then abandoned.
how_to_use: Compute cash sums in days 0–7/0–30 post-onboarding; compare to peers; flag early-life cash intensity.
caveats_false_positives: Legitimate business launch; moving cities; initial setup costs.

title: Dormant → cash burst → dormant
plain_english_explanation: Long inactivity followed by a sharp cash burst and then inactivity again can match temporary laundering ‘runs’.
ocg_relevance: Short-lived laundering campaigns may activate accounts briefly then discard them.
how_to_use: Use rolling volume to identify low-activity periods, a spike, then a drop; score spike-then-drop.

title: Cash transactions at unusual times (night activity)
plain_english_explanation: Cash activity heavily concentrated at late-night hours compared to customer baseline can be suspicious.
ocg_relevance: OCG activity may be scheduled to reduce detection/attention, especially when combined with other red flags.
how_to_use: Compute night_share and change-point vs baseline; flag large shifts.

title: Cash activity across multiple cities/provinces in short time
plain_english_explanation: Cash transactions spread across multiple locations in a short window may indicate coordinated mule networks or travel inconsistent with profile.
ocg_relevance: OCGs may distribute withdrawals/deposits geographically to frustrate tracing.
how_to_use: Compute distinct cities/provinces per 7d/30d; compare to baseline; flag rapid dispersion.
external_enrichment_needed: A distance metric improves precision (requires geocoding).

title: Foreign cash activity vs KYC location
plain_english_explanation: ABM cash transactions in countries different from KYC country can be suspicious (or travel).
ocg_relevance: Cross-border cash activity can be used to complicate tracing, especially in OCG cash-out operations.
how_to_use: Compute pct_cash_txn_outside_kyc_country; flag sudden increases or sustained foreign cash activity.

title: Cash indicator anomalies (ABM records marked non-cash)
plain_english_explanation: ABM records that appear inconsistent with cash indicators may signal data issues that weaken monitoring.
ocg_relevance: Data weaknesses can be exploited by sophisticated laundering; fixing them improves controls.
how_to_use: Validate that ABM channel matches cash_indicator expectations; flag inconsistent records for remediation.
caveats_false_positives: Not an AML signal by itself; it’s a monitoring/data control.

title: Rapid in-and-out movement (high turnover, low net flow)
plain_english_explanation: Customer receives credits and quickly sends debits, creating high turnover with little retained value.
ocg_relevance: Transit accounts are common in professional laundering and mule operations.
how_to_use: Compute rolling inflow/outflow and net flow; flag high inflow+outflow with net near zero and short credit→debit lags.

title: Transaction bursts (many transfers in minutes/hours)
plain_english_explanation: Unusually dense transfer activity in short windows relative to baseline.
ocg_relevance: Bursts may indicate automated laundering or coordinated mule cash-outs.
how_to_use: Compute max count in 10-min/1h windows; z-score vs baseline; flag extreme spikes.

title: Repeated same-amount transfers
plain_english_explanation: Identical transfer amounts repeated unusually often may indicate templated ticket sizes used for laundering.
ocg_relevance: Professional launderers may standardize amounts across mules for operational simplicity.
how_to_use: Compute top amount frequency in 30d and compare to expected; flag high dominance of a single amount.

title: Micro-structuring (many small transfers)
plain_english_explanation: Many small-value transfers clustered in time can indicate smurfing or TF micro-funding patterns.
ocg_relevance: Small, frequent payments are a known typology when combined with other TF/ML signals.
how_to_use: Compute small_txn_count in rolling windows for a chosen ‘small’ band; flag high frequency and sudden increases.
external_enrichment_needed: Define ‘small’ by local context (e.g., <$200) and segment.

title: One credit → many debits (fan-out)
plain_english_explanation: A single inbound credit is followed by multiple outbound debits, dispersing funds quickly.
ocg_relevance: Fan-out is common in layering to fragment funds across routes and reduce traceability.
how_to_use: Within a window after a credit, count subsequent debits; flag high fan-out and short lags.
caveats_false_positives: Bill-paying after payday; business supplier payments.

title: Many credits → one debit (fan-in then cash-out)
plain_english_explanation: Multiple inbound credits consolidate into a larger outbound debit, consistent with mule aggregation.
ocg_relevance: OCGs may aggregate many small deposits then move out in fewer large transfers.
how_to_use: Count credits in the prior window before a large debit; flag high fan-in and large outbound concentration.

title: Same-day credit/debit reversals (wash behavior proxy)
plain_english_explanation: Credits and debits of similar size on the same day can indicate wash-like cycling to obscure traces.
ocg_relevance: Churn patterns can be used to create complexity and noise in audit trails.
how_to_use: For each day, look for paired opposite-direction transactions with similar amounts; count and score.

title: Multi-rail use in tight sequence (EFT↔EMT↔Wire↔Cheque)
plain_english_explanation: Using multiple payment rails in a short period increases complexity and may indicate layering.
ocg_relevance: Professional money launderers often diversify methods to defeat single-channel monitoring.
how_to_use: Count distinct products used per 7d/30d; detect sequences of rail switches within N hours.
caveats_false_positives: Some users legitimately use multiple products.

title: Weekend/holiday-heavy transfers vs baseline
plain_english_explanation: A customer’s transfers become concentrated on weekends/holidays unexpectedly, deviating from prior behavior.
ocg_relevance: Temporal shifts can accompany active laundering phases, especially when co-occurring with velocity signals.
how_to_use: Compute weekend_share and change vs baseline; flag sudden shifts.

title: Non-business-hours transfers (especially for businesses)
plain_english_explanation: Transfers executed mostly outside typical business hours may be suspicious for business profiles.
ocg_relevance: OCG-controlled fronts may operate irregularly; timing anomalies can support suspicion.
how_to_use: Compute night_share; compare businesses vs peer businesses; flag outliers.

title: Single large transfer outlier vs history
plain_english_explanation: A transfer far larger than a customer’s typical history may be suspicious without a reasonable explanation.
ocg_relevance: Large one-off movements can occur in laundering/integration stages; investigate context.
how_to_use: Compute per-customer amount z-score/percentile; flag extreme outliers (both debit and credit).
caveats_false_positives: Legitimate asset sale, inheritance, tuition, taxes.

title: Escalating transfer amounts/volume over time
plain_english_explanation: A steady increase in transaction volume/amounts can indicate scaling laundering activity.
ocg_relevance: OCGs may ramp operations as trust is built with facilitators or after controls appear weak.
how_to_use: Fit simple trend over weekly sums; flag steep growth vs peers and baseline.

title: High remittance frequency/volume (Western Union) vs profile
plain_english_explanation: High or increasing remittance activity (WU) inconsistent with the customer’s profile can be suspicious.
ocg_relevance: Money transfer channels can be exploited for layering or TF; context is critical.
how_to_use: Compute WU sum/count in windows; compare to income/sales and peers; flag outliers and bursts.
external_enrichment_needed: Corridor risk requires receiver country data (not in dataset).

title: Cheque activity spikes and churn (credits/debits)
plain_english_explanation: Unusual cheque volume or churn (credits and debits) compared to baseline may be suspicious.
ocg_relevance: Cheque-based schemes can be used to obscure audit trails; use with other indicators.
how_to_use: Compute cheque sums/counts and churn metrics; flag spikes, reversals, and net-zero behavior.
caveats_false_positives: Business cheque payments; seasonal supplier cycles.

title: Wire transfer spikes/velocity
plain_english_explanation: Unusual wire activity—spikes, rapid in/out, or net-zero behavior—can indicate higher-risk movement.
ocg_relevance: Wires are commonly used in complex layering; anomalies can be high signal.
how_to_use: Compute wire velocity and turnover; flag outliers vs baseline.

title: High e-commerce share (card-not-present heavy)
plain_english_explanation: A large share of card activity is ecommerce, especially if it changes suddenly from prior behavior.
ocg_relevance: OCGs involved in fraud/scams may generate card-not-present patterns that later cash out.
how_to_use: Compute ecommerce_spend_share and ecommerce_txn_share; flag high levels or abrupt shifts.

title: E-commerce bursts followed by outbound transfers
plain_english_explanation: Ecommerce-heavy activity followed by rapid outbound transfers can indicate proceeds movement.
ocg_relevance: Fraud/OCG proceeds often move quickly after collection events; co-occurrence matters.
how_to_use: After ecommerce bursts, measure outbound transfer sums within 24–72h; flag repeat patterns.
caveats_false_positives: Legit online shopping then paying bills.

title: Foreign card activity vs KYC country
plain_english_explanation: Card transactions in countries different from the customer’s KYC country, especially abruptly, can be suspicious.
ocg_relevance: Cross-border activity is a common laundering/TF complexity factor when combined with velocity or channel mixing.
how_to_use: Compute pct_card_txn_outside_kyc_country and change-point vs baseline; flag sustained or sudden foreign activity.

title: Rapid multi-country card activity
plain_english_explanation: Card activity across multiple countries in short windows can be inconsistent with plausible travel patterns.
ocg_relevance: OCGs may route transactions through multiple jurisdictions; interpret carefully due to ecommerce.
how_to_use: Count distinct countries per 7d; flag high counts or abrupt increases.
external_enrichment_needed: Card-present vs ecom separation improves precision (ecommerce_ind helps).

title: Out-of-area card activity vs KYC city/province
plain_english_explanation: A sustained shift away from KYC city/province can indicate mule use or account takeover.
ocg_relevance: Geographic shifts are commonly cited red flags when inconsistent with client profile.
how_to_use: Compute match_rate_to_kyc_city/province; flag sharp decreases and new dominant locations.

title: Spend concentrated in high-risk MCCs (mapping required)
plain_english_explanation: A high share of spend in merchant categories known to be higher-risk can be suspicious.
ocg_relevance: OCG ecosystems can use certain merchant categories for cash-out/value transfer.
how_to_use: Build an MCC risk map; compute risk_mcc_spend_share; flag high shares or sudden spikes.
caveats_false_positives: Some customers legitimately spend in certain categories (e.g., travel).
external_enrichment_needed: Requires an MCC risk taxonomy appropriate to your institution/region.

title: Abrupt merchant-category shift
plain_english_explanation: Customer’s merchant-category mix shifts abruptly (new dominant MCCs) without a plausible reason.
ocg_relevance: Abrupt behavior change is a common suspicious pattern signal when combined with other red flags.
how_to_use: Compute rolling MCC distribution and a distance metric (e.g., Jensen–Shannon); flag large jumps.

title: Many small card debits in short time
plain_english_explanation: High frequency of small card transactions can indicate testing, scam/fraud patterns, or automated use.
ocg_relevance: OCG fraud/scam operations often show high-frequency small-ticket patterns before cash-out.
how_to_use: Define small band; compute small_txn_count_1h/1d and z-score vs baseline; flag extreme bursts.

title: Unusual volume of card credits/refunds
plain_english_explanation: Frequent or large card credits (refunds/returns) can indicate refund fraud or laundering via merchant relationships.
ocg_relevance: Some laundering and fraud typologies exploit refunds/chargebacks; needs context.
how_to_use: Compute credit_count and credit_sum; compare to baseline and peers; flag outliers.

title: High card activity soon after onboarding
plain_english_explanation: A new customer quickly shows high card volume (especially cross-border or ecommerce).
ocg_relevance: Burner/mule accounts may show early intense use.
how_to_use: Compute sums/counts in first 7/30 days; compare to peer new customers; flag outliers.

title: Nighttime card activity shift
plain_english_explanation: Card activity becomes concentrated at unusual hours for the customer.
ocg_relevance: Timing anomalies can support suspicion when combined with other patterns.
how_to_use: Compute night_share vs baseline; flag significant shifts.

title: Card spend inconsistent with declared income/sales
plain_english_explanation: Card spend levels exceed what is plausible given the customer’s KYC income (individual) or sales (business).
ocg_relevance: OCGs often use accounts where observed activity doesn’t match declared means.
how_to_use: Compute monthly card spend; compare to income/sales and peers; flag high multiples.

title: Total inflows/outflows inconsistent with individual income
plain_english_explanation: Total movement of funds (all channels) is far above reported individual income, without a reasonable explanation.
ocg_relevance: Mismatch between means and activity is a widely used risk signal for third‑party laundering.
how_to_use: Compute monthly inflow/outflow across channels and inflow_to_income; flag extreme outliers vs peers/occupation.
caveats_false_positives: Asset sales; transfers between own accounts; outdated KYC.

title: Business flow inconsistent with declared sales
plain_english_explanation: Business transaction volume greatly exceeds declared sales or typical peer behavior.
ocg_relevance: Front companies may be used to co-mingle or move funds beyond their plausible operating scale.
how_to_use: Compute (inflow+outflow)/sales; flag outliers and consider employee_count as operating-footprint proxy.
caveats_false_positives: Rapid business growth; seasonal peaks; stale KYC.

title: Business volume inconsistent with employee count
plain_english_explanation: High transaction activity relative to a very small employee count may suggest the business footprint is inconsistent with flows.
ocg_relevance: OCG fronts may report small footprints while moving large value.
how_to_use: Compute volume per employee and compare to peers; flag extreme outliers.

title: Very young customer with high volume
plain_english_explanation: Customers in very young age bands with unusually high activity can be risk-relevant (depends on context).
ocg_relevance: Mule recruitment and exploitation of younger individuals is common in OCG ecosystems.
how_to_use: Compute age; compare volumes within age bands; flag extreme outliers.

title: Elderly customer with abrupt high-velocity activity
plain_english_explanation: Older customers with sudden high-velocity transfers can signal scam/fraud proceeds movement or exploitation.
ocg_relevance: OCGs often exploit vulnerable populations via scams; patterns can resemble laundering cash-out.
how_to_use: Detect change-point in velocity/volume; flag abrupt shifts in older age bands.
caveats_false_positives: Legitimate estate planning; medical expenses; family support.

title: Occupation mismatch (flows far above occupation peer group)
plain_english_explanation: Activity is extreme compared to others with similar occupation (e.g., low-income roles).
ocg_relevance: Peer comparisons can highlight implausible activity consistent with third‑party laundering.
how_to_use: Join occupation title; compute peer percentiles by occupation; flag outliers.
caveats_false_positives: Occupation may be outdated; side businesses.

title: Industry risk + cash intensity (cash-intensive industry outlier)
plain_english_explanation: Businesses in cash-intensive industries showing extreme cash deposit patterns relative to industry peers.
ocg_relevance: OCGs commonly exploit cash-intensive fronts to mix illicit cash with legitimate revenue.
how_to_use: Tag cash-intensive industries (mapping); compute cash intensity vs peers; flag outliers.
external_enrichment_needed: Requires a cash-intensive industry map (policy decision).

title: Recently established business with unusually high flows
plain_english_explanation: A business with a very recent established_date shows high transaction activity shortly after onboarding.
ocg_relevance: Shell/front entities may be created and used quickly for laundering and then replaced.
how_to_use: Compute months_since_established and early-life volume; flag extreme cases vs peers.
caveats_false_positives: Startups can scale quickly; fundraising events.

title: Transaction geography inconsistent with KYC geography (cross-channel)
plain_english_explanation: Across ABM/card, activity occurs primarily outside the customer’s KYC province/city.
ocg_relevance: Geographic inconsistencies are a standard red flag when unexplained.
how_to_use: Compute location match rates across channels; flag sustained mismatch or abrupt shifts.

title: Customer shows activity in countries different from KYC country
plain_english_explanation: Customer frequently transacts in countries not aligned with their KYC country.
ocg_relevance: Cross-border activity can increase ML/TF risk exposure, especially when combined with velocity or channel mix.
how_to_use: Compute pct_activity_outside_kyc_country and distinct countries; flag spikes or sustained mismatch.

title: Sudden structural change in behavior (customer ‘regime shift’)
plain_english_explanation: A customer’s transaction behavior changes sharply (volume, timing, channels, geography) relative to their own history.
ocg_relevance: OCGs may take over accounts or ‘flip’ usage patterns during laundering campaigns.
how_to_use: Use change-point tests on volumes, channel counts, geo mix, and timing; flag large shifts.
caveats_false_positives: Life events; new job; business expansion.

title: High activity with missing/low-quality KYC attributes (remediation trigger)
plain_english_explanation: High-activity customers with missing key KYC fields should be flagged for remediation because monitoring quality depends on KYC context.
ocg_relevance: Poor KYC quality weakens defenses and can be exploited; fixing it improves model performance and explainability.
how_to_use: Create missingness flags and prioritize remediation for high-volume customers.
caveats_false_positives: Not an AML typology by itself.

title: Outlier vs peer segment (occupation/industry/region)
plain_english_explanation: Customer is a strong outlier compared to peers with similar KYC characteristics.
ocg_relevance: OCGs often operate in pockets; segment outliers can reveal anomalous behavior within a comparable context.
how_to_use: Compute peer percentiles by segment (e.g., industry+province or occupation+province); flag extreme percentiles.
caveats_false_positives: Peer groups can encode bias; use responsibly.

title: Many small outward transfers/remittances (micro-funding proxy)
plain_english_explanation: Sustained small outward payments can be a TF risk signal when inconsistent with profile and combined with other flags.
ocg_relevance: Some TF typologies involve small, repeated payments; requires careful contextual review.
how_to_use: Compute small outbound frequency and persistence; compare to peer group; flag persistent anomalous patterns.
external_enrichment_needed: High-risk corridor/jurisdiction lists and beneficiary data improve detection.

title: Foreign activity + high velocity (escalation for TF/sanctions screening)
plain_english_explanation: When foreign activity spikes and velocity is high, escalate for TF/sanctions review where applicable.
ocg_relevance: International movement plus rapid flows can raise exposure to TF/sanctions risks.
how_to_use: If foreign_share rises and turnover_ratio rises, create an escalation flag (not a determination).

title: Sudden country switch of activity (card/ABM)
plain_english_explanation: Customer’s dominant transaction country changes abruptly, especially without historical precedent.
ocg_relevance: Abrupt jurisdictional changes can align with laundering campaign phases or account compromise.
how_to_use: Compute dominant country per month; detect switches and novelty; flag abrupt changes.

title: High geographic dispersion across cities/provinces
plain_english_explanation: Transactions occur across many cities/provinces in short windows, inconsistent with baseline.
ocg_relevance: OCG networks may distribute activity across locations to reduce detection.
how_to_use: Count distinct locations and compute dispersion metrics; flag spikes.

title: Activity involving high-risk jurisdictions (requires list)
plain_english_explanation: Transactions involving sanctioned/high-risk jurisdictions should be flagged based on external lists.
ocg_relevance: Jurisdictional risk is central to ML/TF risk management, but requires authoritative lists.
how_to_use: Join on high-risk jurisdiction list and compute shares/changes; flag exposures and spikes.
caveats_false_positives: False positives depend on list scope; use governance.
external_enrichment_needed: Requires sanctioned/high-risk jurisdiction lists and policy governance.

title: Multiple indicators triggered together (co-occurrence)
plain_english_explanation: Risk increases when several independent red flags appear together for the same customer.
ocg_relevance: OCG laundering often shows multiple behaviors at once (velocity + mismatch + channel mix).
how_to_use: Count triggered indicators; prioritize higher counts or weighted combinations for investigation.

title: High number of distinct products used (channel breadth)
plain_english_explanation: Using many channels (ABM, card, EFT, EMT, wire, WU, cheque) can indicate layering complexity.
ocg_relevance: Professional launderers diversify methods to reduce single-control effectiveness.
how_to_use: Count distinct product tables with activity per 30d; flag high breadth vs peers.
caveats_false_positives: Some customers are heavy users legitimately.

title: Volume outlier score (unsupervised)
plain_english_explanation: Customer’s overall volume is an extreme outlier relative to population or segment.
ocg_relevance: OCG launders large value; volume outliers can be strong signals when controlled for segment.
how_to_use: Compute robust outlier scores (median/MAD) on monthly totals; flag extreme values.

title: Velocity/turnover outlier score
plain_english_explanation: Customer shows unusually high turnover (in+out) even if totals are moderate.
ocg_relevance: High-velocity ‘transit’ behavior is common in professional laundering and mule cash-out.
how_to_use: Compute turnover_ratio and net_flow; flag outliers, especially near net-zero.

title: Geo hotspot proxy using labels (modeling only)
plain_english_explanation: Aggregate known positives by geography to explore clusters; use cautiously to avoid bias.
ocg_relevance: OCG activity can cluster geographically, but models must be governed to avoid discriminatory outcomes.
how_to_use: Compute label_rate by city/province; use only for analysis/feature engineering with fairness checks.
caveats_false_positives: Risk of socioeconomic bias; do not use as sole decision factor.

title: Transaction without matching KYC record
plain_english_explanation: Customers transacting without a KYC profile reduce monitoring effectiveness and should be remediated.
ocg_relevance: KYC gaps can be exploited by criminals; closing gaps strengthens defenses.
how_to_use: Find customer_ids present in transactions but missing in KYC; escalate remediation.

title: Duplicate transaction_id within a table
plain_english_explanation: Duplicate transaction IDs can distort counts/velocity and cause false alerts or missed risk.
ocg_relevance: Accurate monitoring requires clean data; otherwise patterns become unreliable.
how_to_use: Check uniqueness constraints per table; remediate duplicates.

title: Timestamp quality issues (missing/out-of-order)
plain_english_explanation: Bad timestamps can hide true sequences and compromise detection.
ocg_relevance: Sequence indicators depend on timestamps; ensure data quality before modeling.
how_to_use: Validate parseability, time range, and ordering; flag problematic records.

title: Invalid/unknown country codes in geo fields
plain_english_explanation: Invalid country codes can break geo anomaly / sanctions screening logic.
ocg_relevance: Geographic risk indicators rely on clean jurisdiction data.
how_to_use: Validate ISO-like codes; flag unknown/blank and remediate.

title: Model explanation scaffold: map features back to indicators
plain_english_explanation: Maintain a mapping from engineered features to the indicator(s) they represent for explainability.
ocg_relevance: Explainability is critical for investigator trust and compliance governance.
how_to_use: Create a feature→indicator dictionary so model outputs can be explained as triggered patterns.
